tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "878",
  "action_title": "Restore ponds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of pond restoration for amphibians.
One replicated, before-and-after study in Denmark found that pond restoration had mixed effects on European tree frog population numbers depending on site. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations. Six replicated, before-and-after studies (including one controlled and one site comparison study) in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success. One found that numbers of species did not increase. Two before-and-after studies (including one replicated study) in Estonia found that pond restoration, along with terrestrial habitat management, maintained or increased populations of natterjack toads. One systematic review in the UK found that there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, which often included pond restoration, resulted in self-sustaining great crested newt populations.
One small, replicated study in the USA found that pond restoration had mixed effects on spotted salamander hatching success depending on restoration method.
One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that restoration increased the number of ponds used by breeding natterjack toads. One replicated study in Sweden found that following restoration green toads only reproduced in one of 10 ponds. Three before-and-after studies (including one replicated, controlled study) in Denmark and Italy found that restored and created ponds were colonized by 1–7 species, with 6–65% of ponds colonized and 35% used for breeding."
}

{
  "action_id": "135",
  "action_title": "Manage ditches to benefit wildlife",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Five out of a total eight studies from the Netherlands and the UK (including one replicated, controlled paired study and three replicated site comparisons) looking at the effects of managing ditches on biodiversity, found that this intervention resulted in increased invertebrate biomass or abundance, plant species richness, emergent plant cover, amphibian diversity and abundance, bird visit rates and higher numbers of some bird species or positive impacts on some birds in plots with ditches managed under agri-environment schemes. 
One replicated controlled and paired study from the Netherlands found higher plant diversity on ditch banks along unsprayed edges of winter wheat compared to those sprayed with pesticides. 
Three studies from the Netherlands and the UK (including two replicated site comparisons) found that ditch management had negative or no clear effects on some farmland bird species or plants."
}

{
  "action_id": "880",
  "action_title": "Create wetland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of creating wetlands for amphibians.
Five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies) in the USA compared created to natural wetlands and found that created wetlands had similar numbers of amphibian species, amphibian abundance or communities depending on depth as natural wetlands. Two of the studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of species to adjacent forest. One global review and two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and compared them to natural wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands. Three site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA found that certain amphibian species were only found in created or natural wetlands. 
One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."
}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2966",
  "action_title": "Exclude or remove livestock from historically grazed freshwater marshes",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of excluding or removing livestock from historically grazed freshwater marshes. Seven studies were in the USA, two were in Morocco and one was in Australia. In all 10 studies the focal livestock included cattle (mixed with sheep in the two studies in Morocco). Two studies in the USA were based on the same experimental set-up, and the two studies in Morocco shared some study sites.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY

Community composition (4 studies): Two site comparison studies in Morocco and the USA reported that marshes/pools fenced to exclude livestock for 3–30 years contained a different overall plant community to grazed sites. In the USA, the precise effect depended on the time since exclusion. Two replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies in marshes in Australia and the USA found that fencing to exclude cattle typically had no significant effect on the overall plant community composition after 1–14 years. One of the studies also found that the plant community in fenced and grazed marshes was of similar quality, relative to pristine local marshes.
Relative abundance (3 studies): Of three replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies that reported data on the relative abundance of plant groups, two studies (based on one experimental set-up) in the USA found that ephemeral pools fenced to exclude cattle for 1–10 years had similar or greater cover of grasses relative to forbs than pools that remained grazed. The other study, also in the USA, found that the relative abundance of forbs, grass-like plants and shrubs was similar in marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 1–3 years and marshes that remained grazed.
Overall richness/diversity (6 studies): Four replicated studies (two also randomized, paired, controlled) in the USA, Morocco and Australia found that marshes/pools fenced to exclude cattle, for 1–30 years, typically had similar overall plant species richness to sites that remained grazed. One of the studies found that the same was true for overall plant diversity. One replicated, site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years had similar (in a dry year) or greater (in a wet year) plant species richness compared to pools that remained grazed. One site comparison study in the USA found that marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 3–13 years contained fewer plant species than grazed marshes, and had similar or lower plant diversity.
Characteristic plant richness/diversity (1 study): One site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years contained a similar number of wetland-characteristic plant species to pools that remained grazed.
Native/non-target richness/diversity (3 studies): Of three replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies that reported data on native plant species richness, two studies (based on one experimental set-up) in the USA found that fencing ephemeral pools to exclude cattle for 1–10 years typically reduced native plant species richness. The other study, also in the USA, found that native plant species richness was similar in marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 1–3 years and marshes that remained grazed.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Overall abundance (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies in the USA and Morocco found that ponds/pools fenced to exclude cattle for >10 years contained more vegetation than sites that remained grazed. This was measured in terms of emergent cover around pond margins or peak above-ground biomass in ephemeral pools. One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in Australia found that marshes fenced to exclude cattle for ≤4 years contained similar above-ground vegetation biomass to marshes that remained grazed.
Characteristic plant abundance (1 study): One site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that the overall abundance of wetland-characteristic plant species was greater in pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years than in pools that remained grazed.
Herb abundance (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that fencing pastures to exclude cattle typically increased herb cover in wetlands along creeks, but had no significant effect on herb cover within spring wetlands.
Individual species abundance (2 studies): Two replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies in freshwater marshes in Australia and the USA quantified the effect of this action on the abundance of individual plant species (see original papers for data).

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Visual obstruction (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that ponds fenced to exclude cattle for >10 years had greater horizontal vegetation cover, around their margins, than ponds that remained grazed.
Height (2 studies): Two replicated studies (one also randomized, paired, controlled, before-and-after) in the USA found that fencing ponds to exclude cattle, for 1–3 or >10 years, increased the height of vegetation around their margins."
}

{
  "action_id": "869",
  "action_title": "Create ponds for amphibians",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-eight studies investigated the colonization of created ponds by amphibians in general (rather than by targeted species, which are discussed below). All of the studies found that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
Nine site comparison studies (including seven replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA compared amphibian numbers in created and natural ponds. Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. Four found that species composition differed, and comparisons between abundance of individual species, juvenile productivity and size at metamorphosis differed depending on species. One found that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. One found that populations in created ponds were less stable.
One review and two replicated, before-and-after studies in Denmark and the USA found that amphibians established stable populations in 50–100% of created ponds. Six replicated studies (including one randomized study) in France, the Netherlands, UK and USA found that amphibians used 64–100% and reproduced in 64–68% of created ponds, or used 8–100% and reproduced in 2–62% depending on species. One review and 15 studies (including 12 replicated studies, one of which was randomized) in Europe and the USA found that created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species, up to 10 species that reproduced, as well as by captive-bred amphibians. Five replicated studies (including three site comparison studies) in Denmark, Estonia, France, Italy and the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained and increased amphibian populations or increased numbers of species.
Seven studies (including one review) in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish."
}

{
  "action_id": "3730",
  "action_title": "Create or restore ponds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects of creating or restoring ponds on reptile populations. Two studies were in the USA and one was in each of Austria and China.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (4 STUDIES)

Use (4 studies): Four studies (including one replicated and one before-and-after study) in Austria, the USA and China reported that following the creation of ponds, in one case 30–60 years after pond creation, or restoration of a river island that included creation of ponds grass snakes and sand lizards were found on the island, and ponds were occupied by mangrove salt marsh snakaes, common snapping turtles and midland painted turtles and Chinese alligators."
}

query: What interventions are available for creating or providing shelter habitats for amphibians, such as refuges or hibernation sites?
relevant_summary: Interventions reported for providing shelter habitats for amphibians include: creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites, which maintained great crested newt populations when implemented with other terrestrial habitat management, were used by common frog and smooth newts, and had four amphibian species recorded close to hibernacula at two of three sites [759]; creating refuges, including installing artificial refugia and reintroducing coarse woody debris, which helped maintain great crested newt populations when combined with other interventions, were used by translocated Hamilton’s frogs and by hellbenders (with few used for breeding), and showed mixed effects of adding coarse woody debris on amphibian abundance and species number, with one restoration project increasing frog species following reintroduction of coarse woody debris [772]; leaving coarse woody debris in forests, which yielded mixed responses, including no significant differences in abundance for many species when debris was retained vs removed, higher use of clearcuts with debris retained by migrating amphibians, and higher survival of juvenile amphibians in piles of woody debris compared to open areas and similar to unharvested forest [843]; and creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats, for which no studies were found that directly tested effects on amphibian populations [813].

{
  "action_id": "3720",
  "action_title": "Create artificial refuges, hibernacula and aestivation sites",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of creating artificial refuges, hibernacula and aestivation sites on reptile populations. Three studies were in each of the UK and Australia, two were in New Zealand and one was in each of the USA, Spain and Italy.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that areas with refuge logs had higher reptile species richness than areas without refuges.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (1 study): One controlled, before-and-after study in Spain found that areas with refuge logs had a higher abundance of reptiles than areas without refuges.
Reproductive success (1 study): One study in the UK found that after translocating adders to an artificial hibernaculum, there was evidence of successful reproduction.
Survival (1 study): One randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in New Zealand found that in areas with artificial refuges, survival of McCann’s skinks was similar to areas without refuges.

BEHAVIOUR (9 STUDIES)

Use (9 studies): Nine studies (including one replicated, controlled study and one randomized, controlled study) in the USA, the UK, Australia, New Zealand and Italy found that artificial refuges were used by reptiles, common lizards, adders, common geckos, species of skinks, and by an ocellated lizard to lay a clutch of eggs. Four of the studies also found that some reptiles showed a preference for refuges with certain designs or construction materials."
}

{
  "action_id": "843",
  "action_title": "Leave coarse woody debris in forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that there was no significant difference in abundance in clearcuts with woody debris retained or removed for eight of nine amphibian species, but that the overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians was more negative where woody debris was retained.
Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that the removal of coarse woody debris from standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall amphibian abundance, but did reduce species richness in one study.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed.
One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that within clearcut forest, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas, and was similar in wood piles to unharvested forest."
}

{
  "action_id": "3732",
  "action_title": "Create or restore rock outcrops",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects of creating or restoring rock outcrops on reptile populations. All five studies were in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One replicated, paired sites, controlled study in Australia found that areas restored with artificial rocks had a higher abundance of adult velvet geckos and similar numbers of juveniles compared to unrestored areas.
Survival (1 study): One replicated, paired sites, controlled study in Australia found that in areas restored with artificial rocks, juvenile velvet geckos had higher survival rates than in unrestored areas.

BEHAVIOUR (4 STUDIES)

Use (4 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia found that some restored rocky outcrops were recolonized by pink-tailed worm-lizards. One replicated, controlled study in Australia found that constructed rock outcrops were used by two snake and six lizard species at least as often as natural outcrops. Two replicated studies (including one randomized study) in Australia found that artificial rock outcrops were used by two lizard and one snake species and six lizard and two snake species. One study also found that unshaded artificial rocks were used more frequently by velvet geckos than shaded ones."
}

{
  "action_id": "2653",
  "action_title": "Gather coarse woody debris into piles after felling",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects on mammals of gathering coarse woody debris into piles after felling. Both studies were in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): A randomized, replicated, controlled study in Canada found higher mammal species richness where coarse woody debris was gathered into piles.

POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One of two randomized, replicated, controlled studies in Canada found higher counts of San Bernardino long-tailed voles where coarse woody debris was gathered into piles. The other study found higher small mammal abundance at one of three plots where debris was gathered into piles.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: What factors and interventions have influenced the success of natterjack toad conservation projects in the UK?
relevant_summary:
- Creating ponds (often alongside other interventions) increased natterjack toad populations or maintained/increased populations at many sites; compared to natural ponds, created ponds had lower tadpole mortality from desiccation but higher mortality from invertebrate predation (866). 
- Translocations established breeding populations in 30–70% of cases; success was higher on dune or saltmarsh than heathland, and a UK study found populations increased at translocation sites, particularly with replicated translocations of wild rather than captive-bred toads (859). 
- Adding limestone to ponds showed mixed results in the UK: establishment of one of three translocated populations; temporary increases in breeding and increased larval/egg survival at some sites; but also high tadpole mortality, pond abandonment, and more abnormal common frog eggs at other sites (748). 
- Grazing management produced varied outcomes: a replicated, controlled UK study found grazed plots did not have higher natterjack abundance than ungrazed, while other studies that included reintroduction of grazing as part of habitat management maintained or increased natterjack populations (780). 
- Vegetation clearance, as part of broader habitat management and sometimes alongside releases, increased, stabilized or maintained natterjack populations; an England study recorded increased occupancy following vegetation clearance (761). 
- Deepening, de-silting or re-profiling ponds, when combined with other interventions, increased natterjack toad populations in UK studies (817).

query: What are the general outcomes and challenges associated with captive breeding programs for different amphibian groups like frogs, toads, and salamanders?
relevant_summary: Across frogs, many studies reported egg production in captivity, sometimes by captive‑bred females, with several cases of mixed success (some species or 17–50% of captive populations reproducing) and occasional failures; survival outcomes ranged from successful rearing to hatching, tadpoles, froglets, or adults, but included low froglet survival in some cases, and reproductive success depended on factors such as temperature and simulated wet/dry seasons, while development was affected by parental care, density, and temperature [835]. For salamanders, eggs were produced successfully in several studies, but success varied with tank habitat and was higher in semi‑natural than laboratory settings in some cases; some species produced eggs that did not hatch, one study reported 60% survival to hatching for Japanese giant salamanders, and larval development, body condition, and survival were influenced by water temperature, density, and rearing environment [838]. Hormone treatments commonly stimulated or increased sperm production and sometimes enabled successful captive breeding, but female responses were mixed (about 30–71% producing viable eggs depending on hormone regimes), and in some cases hormone‑induced breeding did not occur; eggs induced by hormones were sometimes raised to tadpoles or froglets, though two studies reported most toads died before or soon after hatching [883]. Using a surrogate species to refine husbandry promoted successful breeding of a critically endangered frog [1862]. Providing enclosure features (e.g., rotting logs, hollow bamboo, varied substrates) and simulating wet/dry seasons promoted breeding in captive frogs [1876], while altering enclosure lighting to add UV did not increase clutch size and was associated with greater fungal load [1865]. Cryopreservation showed that sperm viability after freezing varied by species, cryoprotectant, and storage/handling conditions, with some methods yielding higher viability, but overall viability could be low even though storage up to 58 weeks was possible [876].

{
  "action_id": "835",
  "action_title": "Captive breeding frogs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty-three studies investigated the success of breeding frogs in captivity.
Twenty-three of 33 studies, three of which were reviews and 30 replicated studies, across the world found that amphibians produced egg in captivity, in four cases by captive-bred females. Seven found mixed results, with some species of frogs or 17–50% of captive populations  reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. One found that frogs did not breed successfully in captivity and another that all breeding frogs died. Seventeen of the studies found that captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults in captivity. One found that froglet survival was low and another that three species were not successfully raised to adulthood.
Four replicated studies (including one small study) in,Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong and Italy found that 30–88% of eggs hatched or survival to metamorphosis was 75%, as froglets was 17–51% or to adults was 50–90% in captivity.
One review and four replicated studies (including two small studies) in Germany, Italy and the USA found that reproductive success of frogs in captivity depended on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season, but not on whether frogs were housed in high or low maintenance facilities. Three replicated studies (including one small study) in Germany, Australia and Canada found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature."
}

query: As an alternative to creating entirely new ponds, what actions can be taken to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates several ways to restore or enhance existing water bodies for amphibians: Restoring existing ponds has been associated with increased species numbers, pond occupancy, breeding use, and maintained or increased populations in multiple studies, though effects varied by site and species [878]. Regulating or maintaining pond water levels has been linked to increased natterjack toad populations, maintained newt populations, successful breeding of dusky gopher frogs, and in some cases increased abundance and species numbers when ponds were seasonally drained [833]. Removing or controlling fish by periodically drying ponds has increased numbers of amphibian species and breeding success for several species in multiple studies [826]. Deepening, de-silting, or re-profiling ponds has been associated with establishment or increase of breeding populations and maintained or increased populations in several studies [817]. Reducing pond shading by removing tree canopy was part of restoration associated with establishment of breeding in translocated garlic toads, although one study found no increase in hatching success for spotted salamanders [758]. Excluding livestock or wild hogs by fencing has shown mixed effects overall but included increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads following restoration that included livestock exclusion [746]. Adding limestone to reduce acidification has produced varied outcomes, including temporary increases in breeding or higher larval/egg survival in some cases, but also high tadpole mortality or pond abandonment in others [748]. Managing surrounding vegetation and water quality through buffer approaches showed mixed results: planting riparian buffer strips along streams did not increase abundance or species numbers in one study [819]; retaining buffer strips during timber harvest had mixed to positive effects depending on species and buffer width [747]; and retaining or leaving unmown buffers around ponds increased numbers of frog species in one case, with mixed tadpole responses elsewhere [850]. Controlling invasive plants (e.g., swamp stonecrop, reed canarygrass) was associated with population increases or preferred egg-laying areas for some amphibians [823].

{
  "action_id": "878",
  "action_title": "Restore ponds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of pond restoration for amphibians.
One replicated, before-and-after study in Denmark found that pond restoration had mixed effects on European tree frog population numbers depending on site. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations. Six replicated, before-and-after studies (including one controlled and one site comparison study) in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success. One found that numbers of species did not increase. Two before-and-after studies (including one replicated study) in Estonia found that pond restoration, along with terrestrial habitat management, maintained or increased populations of natterjack toads. One systematic review in the UK found that there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, which often included pond restoration, resulted in self-sustaining great crested newt populations.
One small, replicated study in the USA found that pond restoration had mixed effects on spotted salamander hatching success depending on restoration method.
One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that restoration increased the number of ponds used by breeding natterjack toads. One replicated study in Sweden found that following restoration green toads only reproduced in one of 10 ponds. Three before-and-after studies (including one replicated, controlled study) in Denmark and Italy found that restored and created ponds were colonized by 1–7 species, with 6–65% of ponds colonized and 35% used for breeding."
}

Twelve studies investigated the effectiveness of retaining buffer strips during timber harvest for amphibians.

{
  "action_id": "869",
  "action_title": "Create ponds for amphibians",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-eight studies investigated the colonization of created ponds by amphibians in general (rather than by targeted species, which are discussed below). All of the studies found that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
Nine site comparison studies (including seven replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA compared amphibian numbers in created and natural ponds. Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. Four found that species composition differed, and comparisons between abundance of individual species, juvenile productivity and size at metamorphosis differed depending on species. One found that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. One found that populations in created ponds were less stable.
One review and two replicated, before-and-after studies in Denmark and the USA found that amphibians established stable populations in 50–100% of created ponds. Six replicated studies (including one randomized study) in France, the Netherlands, UK and USA found that amphibians used 64–100% and reproduced in 64–68% of created ponds, or used 8–100% and reproduced in 2–62% depending on species. One review and 15 studies (including 12 replicated studies, one of which was randomized) in Europe and the USA found that created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species, up to 10 species that reproduced, as well as by captive-bred amphibians. Five replicated studies (including three site comparison studies) in Denmark, Estonia, France, Italy and the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained and increased amphibian populations or increased numbers of species.
Seven studies (including one review) in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish."
}

{
  "action_id": "880",
  "action_title": "Create wetland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of creating wetlands for amphibians.
Five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies) in the USA compared created to natural wetlands and found that created wetlands had similar numbers of amphibian species, amphibian abundance or communities depending on depth as natural wetlands. Two of the studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of species to adjacent forest. One global review and two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and compared them to natural wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands. Three site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA found that certain amphibian species were only found in created or natural wetlands. 
One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."
}

  "action_id": "879",
  "action_title": "Restore wetland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Seventeen studies investigated the effectiveness of wetland restoration for amphibians.
Ten site comparison studies (including eight replicated studies) in Canada and the USA compared amphibian numbers in restored and natural wetlands. Eight found that amphibian abundance, numbers of species and species composition were similar. Two found that the number of species or abundance was lower and species composition different in restored wetlands. One found that restored wetlands were used more or less depending on the habitat surrounding natural wetlands. One global review found that in 89% of cases, restored and created wetlands had similar or higher amphibian abundance or numbers of species to natural wetlands.
Seven of nine studies (including six site comparison and/or replicated studies) in Canada, Taiwan and the USA found that wetland restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, with breeding populations establishing in some cases. Three found that numbers of species or abundance did not increase with restoration. Two found mixed effects, with restoration maintaining or increasing abundance of individual species. Three replicated studies (including two site comparison studies) in the USA found that numbers of species in restored wetlands were affected by wetland size, proximity to source ponds and seasonality, but not wetland age.
Three studies (including two replicated, site comparison studies) in Taiwan and the USA found that restored wetlands were colonized by three to eight amphibian species. One before-and-after study in the USA found that three target species did not recolonize restored wetlands."
}

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different direct treatments for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis?
relevant_summary: Antifungal drugs: Across 16 studies, 12 reported cure or increased survival following antifungal treatment, while four reported no cure but reduced infection levels or mixed results; six studies noted mortality or other adverse effects from specific fungicides [882]. Itraconazole specifically was effective at curing infections in six of eight studies; one study found reduced infection levels and one found mixed effects [882]. Field or pre-release treatment: A before-and-after study treating wild midwife toads with fungicide alongside pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis [767]. Probiotics/antimicrobial skin interventions: In four randomized, replicated, controlled studies, three found that adding antifungal bacteria to salamanders or frogs did not reduce infection rate or death, while one found prevention of infection and death; adding antifungal bacteria to soil reduced infection rate of red-backed salamanders in one study; antimicrobial skin peptides given before or after infection did not increase survival of common toads; three studies found adding antifungal skin bacteria reduced weight loss in infected amphibians [764]. Heat/temperature treatment: In five studies (four replicated, controlled), four found that raising enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads, whereas one found that 30–35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs [770].

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of retaining habitat features like riparian buffers, coarse woody debris, and snags during timber harvesting?
relevant_summary: Riparian buffers: For amphibians, studies comparing clearcuts with and without buffers reported mixed effects on abundance depending on species and buffer width, with one study finding higher abundance with buffers; compared to unharvested forest, some studies found similar abundance and composition, others found lower numbers; wider buffers sometimes supported greater species numbers and abundance, though not consistently (747). No studies were found assessing effects of riparian buffers during harvest on mammals or on butterflies and moths (2652; 3872). Coarse woody debris (CWD): In amphibians, retaining CWD in clearcuts produced no significant abundance difference for most species but overall amphibian responses (population, physiological, behavioural) were more negative where debris was retained; removing CWD in standing forest did not reduce diversity or overall abundance but reduced species richness in one study; migrating amphibians used clearcuts with retained debris more, and juvenile survival was higher in debris piles than open areas and similar to unharvested forest (843). In mammals, retaining/adding CWD yielded mixed outcomes: one study found more small mammal species groups where debris was present, another found higher numbers for two of three shrew species with increased CWD, while other studies reported no increase in small mammal numbers or records (2647). Gathering debris into piles increased mammal species richness and, in some cases, increased vole counts and small mammal abundance (2653). In reptiles, leaving debris after logging generally produced no changes in richness or abundance, though one study found higher richness and abundance than where debris was cleared and burned (3632). For birds, removing woody debris reduced overall breeding bird abundance and diversity and lowered nest survival for black-chinned hummingbirds, though some species increased after removal (345). Snags/standing deadwood: For reptiles, increasing snags and woody debris had mixed or no effects on diversity and abundance (3631). For amphibians, leaving dead or wildlife trees during clearcutting did not increase salamander abundances compared to total clearcutting, did not prevent abundance declines or composition changes relative to unharvested plots, and reproductive metrics were similar or lower in harvested plots including those with retained dead/wildlife trees (845). Variable retention (retaining structural elements such as live trees/snags): bird responses were mixed, with nine species at higher densities and five at lower densities in variable-retention stands relative to controls (332).

Six studies evaluated the effects of adding woody debris to landscapes on reptile populations. Three studies were in Australia, two were in the USA and one was in Indonesia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "843",
  "action_title": "Leave coarse woody debris in forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that there was no significant difference in abundance in clearcuts with woody debris retained or removed for eight of nine amphibian species, but that the overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians was more negative where woody debris was retained.
Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that the removal of coarse woody debris from standing forest did not decrease amphibian diversity or overall amphibian abundance, but did reduce species richness in one study.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed.
One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that within clearcut forest, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas, and was similar in wood piles to unharvested forest."
}

{
  "action_id": "2647",
  "action_title": "Leave coarse woody debris in forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Three studies evaluated the effects on mammals of leaving coarse woody debris in forests. One study was in Canada, one was in the USA and one was in Malaysia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): A replicated, site comparison study, in Malaysia found more small mammal species groups in felled forest areas with woody debris than without.

POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Abundance (3 studies): One out of three replicated studies (two controlled, one site comparison, one before-and-after) in Canada, the USA and Malaysia found that retaining or adding coarse woody debris did not increase numbers or frequency of records of small mammals. The other study found that two of three shrew species were more numerous in areas with increased volumes of coarse woody debris than areas without coarse woody debris.

query: How effective are conservation actions such as legal protection, habitat creation, and translocation for great crested newt populations in the UK?
relevant_summary: Evidence from UK-focused action documents indicates mixed effectiveness. For translocation, four of six studies (including one review and one replicated study) in the UK found translocated great crested newts maintained or established breeding populations; however, populations were present one year after release in 37% of cases, one study reported breeding failed in 48% of ponds within three years, and a systematic review of 31 great crested newt studies found no conclusive evidence that mitigation including translocations resulted in self-sustaining populations; a UK review reported reproduction following 56% of translocations, sometimes alongside head-starting and/or habitat management [858]. For habitat creation, creating ponds led to breeding populations at 57–75% of created ponds or sites in studies from Germany and the UK; a UK systematic review concluded there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, often including pond creation, produced self-sustaining populations; up to 88% of created ponds were colonized by translocated or naturally colonizing great crested newts, and head-started newts reproduced in 38% of created ponds [863]. For terrestrial habitat structures, one replicated before-and-after UK study found artificial hibernacula provided with other terrestrial habitat management maintained great crested newt populations; other replicated studies reported created hibernacula were used by common frog and smooth newts but not great crested newts, and four amphibian species were found close to hibernacula at two of three sites [759]. Regarding legal protection in the development context, three reviews (including a systematic review) in the Netherlands and UK found legal protection of amphibians was not effective at protecting populations during development, while two UK reviews reported that great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales [779].

query: What is the evidence regarding the long-term success and timeframes for amphibian populations to respond to habitat restoration, such as replanting or vegetation clearance?
relevant_summary: Vegetation clearance, often combined with other habitat management and sometimes animal releases, increased numbers of frog species or increased, stabilized, or maintained natterjack toad populations; one study reported increased occupancy by natterjack toads, and another found a great crested newt population was maintained for the first six years after management that included vegetation clearance but not in the longer term [761]. Replanting-based restoration showed amphibian abundance or community composition similar to natural sites after tree planting, or becoming more similar with increasing time since grassland reseeding; numbers of frog species increased following restoration that included planting shrubs and trees; after logging, planted forests with herbicide had amphibian abundance lower or similar to naturally regenerating forests depending on species and forest age; amphibians colonized replanted forest, reseeded grassland, and seeded/transplanted upland habitats; wetlands in reseeded grasslands were used more frequently than those in farmland but less than in natural grasslands [849].

  "action_title": "Retain riparian buffer strips during timber harvest",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twelve studies investigated the effectiveness of retaining buffer strips during timber harvest for amphibians.
Six replicated and/or controlled studies in Canada and the USA compared amphibian numbers following clearcutting with or without riparian buffer strips. Five found mixed effects on abundance depending on species and buffer width. One found that amphibian abundance was significantly higher with buffers.
Eleven studies, including 10 replicated and/or controlled studies in Canada and the USA and one meta-analysis, compared amphibian numbers in forest with riparian buffers retained during harvest to unharvested forest. Six found mixed effects depending on species or volume of existing downed wood. Four found that abundance and species composition were similar to unharvested forest. Two found that numbers of species and abundance were lower than in unharvested forest.
Two of four replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled, before-and-after study) in Canada and the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance were greater in wider riparian buffer strips. Two found that there was no difference in abundance in buffers of different widths."
}

query: What are the most beneficial actions for creating or restoring aquatic habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary: Wetland restoration: In site comparisons, most studies found restored wetlands had amphibian abundance, species numbers, or communities similar to natural wetlands; some found lower numbers or different communities; a global review reported 89% of cases showed similar or higher abundance or species numbers in restored/created vs natural wetlands (879). Multiple studies found restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, with breeding populations establishing in some cases; effects varied among species and were influenced by wetland size, proximity to source ponds, and seasonality, but not wetland age; restored wetlands were colonized by 3–8 amphibian species, though one study found three target species did not recolonize (879). Pond restoration: Across before-and-after studies, restoration and creation often increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, increased pond occupancy, and increased the number of ponds with breeding success; some studies found no increase or mixed effects depending on species or site; colonization of restored/created ponds ranged from 6–65% of ponds, with 35% used for breeding in one set of studies (878). Wetland creation: Site comparisons commonly found similar amphibian species numbers or abundance to natural wetlands, though some studies reported fewer species or lower abundance; created wetlands were colonized or used by 4–15 amphibian species; numbers of species and abundance were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence, and distance to source wetlands; a review and studies combining created and restored wetlands found species numbers and abundance higher or similar than natural wetlands in most cases (880). Pond creation: All studies reported amphibians used some or all created ponds; in comparisons with natural ponds, numbers of species or breeding species were often similar or higher, though species composition frequently differed and populations could be less stable; stable populations established in 50–100% of created ponds in some studies; use occurred in 64–100% and reproduction in 2–68% of created ponds depending on species; up to 15 species colonized and up to 10 reproduced; outcomes were influenced by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds, and fish presence (869). Riparian buffer strips: Planting buffer strips along streams did not increase amphibian abundance, numbers of species, or adult-to-tadpole ratios in one replicated, controlled study (819).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "879",
  "action_title": "Restore wetland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Seventeen studies investigated the effectiveness of wetland restoration for amphibians.
Ten site comparison studies (including eight replicated studies) in Canada and the USA compared amphibian numbers in restored and natural wetlands. Eight found that amphibian abundance, numbers of species and species composition were similar. Two found that the number of species or abundance was lower and species composition different in restored wetlands. One found that restored wetlands were used more or less depending on the habitat surrounding natural wetlands. One global review found that in 89% of cases, restored and created wetlands had similar or higher amphibian abundance or numbers of species to natural wetlands.
Seven of nine studies (including six site comparison and/or replicated studies) in Canada, Taiwan and the USA found that wetland restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, with breeding populations establishing in some cases. Three found that numbers of species or abundance did not increase with restoration. Two found mixed effects, with restoration maintaining or increasing abundance of individual species. Three replicated studies (including two site comparison studies) in the USA found that numbers of species in restored wetlands were affected by wetland size, proximity to source ponds and seasonality, but not wetland age.
Three studies (including two replicated, site comparison studies) in Taiwan and the USA found that restored wetlands were colonized by three to eight amphibian species. One before-and-after study in the USA found that three target species did not recolonize restored wetlands."
}

{
  "action_id": "878",
  "action_title": "Restore ponds",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of pond restoration for amphibians.
One replicated, before-and-after study in Denmark found that pond restoration had mixed effects on European tree frog population numbers depending on site. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration did not increase great crested newt populations. Six replicated, before-and-after studies (including one controlled and one site comparison study) in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success. One found that numbers of species did not increase. Two before-and-after studies (including one replicated study) in Estonia found that pond restoration, along with terrestrial habitat management, maintained or increased populations of natterjack toads. One systematic review in the UK found that there was no conclusive evidence that mitigation, which often included pond restoration, resulted in self-sustaining great crested newt populations.
One small, replicated study in the USA found that pond restoration had mixed effects on spotted salamander hatching success depending on restoration method.
One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that restoration increased the number of ponds used by breeding natterjack toads. One replicated study in Sweden found that following restoration green toads only reproduced in one of 10 ponds. Three before-and-after studies (including one replicated, controlled study) in Denmark and Italy found that restored and created ponds were colonized by 1–7 species, with 6–65% of ponds colonized and 35% used for breeding."
}

{
  "action_id": "880",
  "action_title": "Create wetland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Fifteen studies investigated the effectiveness of creating wetlands for amphibians.
Five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies) in the USA compared created to natural wetlands and found that created wetlands had similar numbers of amphibian species, amphibian abundance or communities depending on depth as natural wetlands. Two of the studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands had similar numbers of species to adjacent forest. One global review and two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and compared them to natural wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands. Three site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in the USA found that certain amphibian species were only found in created or natural wetlands. 
One before-and-after study in Australia found that captive-bred green and golden bell frog tadpoles released into a created wetland did not establish a self-sustaining population.
Five studies (including two replicated studies) in Kenya and the USA that investigated colonization of created wetlands found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized the wetlands. One global review and three studies (including two replicated studies) in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species and amphibian abundance in created wetlands were affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands."
}

{
  "action_id": "869",
  "action_title": "Create ponds for amphibians",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-eight studies investigated the colonization of created ponds by amphibians in general (rather than by targeted species, which are discussed below). All of the studies found that amphibians used some or all created ponds.
Nine site comparison studies (including seven replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA compared amphibian numbers in created and natural ponds. Five found that numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds, and numbers of ponds colonized were similar. Four found that species composition differed, and comparisons between abundance of individual species, juvenile productivity and size at metamorphosis differed depending on species. One found that numbers of species were similar or lower depending on the permanence of created water bodies. One found that populations in created ponds were less stable.
One review and two replicated, before-and-after studies in Denmark and the USA found that amphibians established stable populations in 50–100% of created ponds. Six replicated studies (including one randomized study) in France, the Netherlands, UK and USA found that amphibians used 64–100% and reproduced in 64–68% of created ponds, or used 8–100% and reproduced in 2–62% depending on species. One review and 15 studies (including 12 replicated studies, one of which was randomized) in Europe and the USA found that created ponds were used or colonized by up to 15 naturally colonizing species, up to 10 species that reproduced, as well as by captive-bred amphibians. Five replicated studies (including three site comparison studies) in Denmark, Estonia, France, Italy and the USA found that pond creation, and restoration in three cases, maintained and increased amphibian populations or increased numbers of species.
Seven studies (including one review) in Austria, Denmark, Poland, the Netherlands and USA found that use or colonization of or reproductive success in created ponds was affected by pond age, permanence, vegetation cover, surrounding landscape, distance to existing ponds and presence of fish."
}

Seven studies evaluated the effects of creating or restoring wetlands on reptile populations. Six studies were in the USA and one was in Kenya.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): One before-and-after, site comparison study in the USA found that reptile species richness and diversity tended to be lower in a restored wetland compared to an undisturbed wetland. One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that created, restored, enhanced and natural wetlands had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness. One site comparison study in the USA found that created wetlands and adjacent natural forest had similar reptile species richness and diversity.

POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Reproductive success (2 studies): One site comparison study in the USA found that a created wetland was used by snapping turtles for egg laying. One before-and-after, site comparison study in the USA found that in a restored wetland, 16 snake, six lizard and eight turtle species successfully reproduced.

BEHAVIOUR (4 STUDIES)

Use (4 studies): One site comparison study and three before-and-after studies (including one replicated study) in the USA and Kenya found that created or restored wetlands were used by black rat snakes and snapping turtles, turtles, lizards, green grass snakes and terrapins, six or 18 reptile species."

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of using chemical treatments for amphibian conservation?
relevant_summary: Antifungal treatments for chytridiomycosis cured infections or increased survival in most reported studies, though some studies found only reduced infection levels or mixed results [882]. Itraconazole specifically was effective at curing amphibians in most tests, with some studies showing reduced infection levels or mixed effects [882]. Some specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians [882]. Pond drying combined with fungicidal treatment reduced infection levels in resident midwife toads but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis [766]. Adding salt to a pond where chytrid fungus was present was followed by a green and golden bell frog population remaining free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months [762]. Disinfectant use for sterilizing equipment showed no evidence on disease spread outcomes; Virkon S did not affect survival, mass or behavior of frog and toad larvae, while bleach significantly reduced tadpole survival in one study [768].
